How do I register an identity using the command line with Verus?

You can register an identity using the `registeridentity` command with Verus. The basic format of the command is:

```
verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "<txid>","namereservation": {... }, "identity": {... }}' false 0 <private_key>
```

You need to replace `<txid>` with the transaction ID of the name reservation, and `<private_key>` with the private key associated with the identity. The `namereservation` and `identity` objects contain the details of the name reservation and identity registration, respectively.

verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "67635331cbccb7a2cbf408a9e97b3f8986133964e0315a8b9fd237a5fd95ac8f","namereservation": { "version": 1, "name": "ID", "parent": "i84mndBk2Znydpgm9T9pTjVvBnHkhErzLt", "salt": "b7070f2ca7495e49c85ab41b5a368150e2c217be6d08cc4102a1b682cddb6f01", "referral": ""},"identity":{"primaryaddresses":["RDnf7mH7RQki9b7PqdBD2Er6WXv3DTawGr"],"minimumsignatures":1,"name":"ID","parent":"vrsc-btc@"}}' false 0 zs1s2mteau9tcalvk55cnepw3aq7dr6w7f447pqqkxczat3a02208d3ersx60wz9srw3nkd25ppfny ``` If a currency's ID issuance require permission from the currency's identity then it must sign the name commitment and identity registration. Either use the parent identity to fund those transactions, or receive a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage! Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:The enclosed copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all copies or substantial portions of the Software.
./raw_txt_input/release_notes.md
What is the purpose of the `returntx` option when registering an identity?

The `returntx` option is used to receive a raw transaction that the identity owner needs to sign if the currency's ID issuance requires permission from the currency's identity. This allows the identity owner to sign the name commitment and identity registration transactions.

verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "67635331cbccb7a2cbf408a9e97b3f8986133964e0315a8b9fd237a5fd95ac8f","namereservation": { "version": 1, "name": "ID", "parent": "i84mndBk2Znydpgm9T9pTjVvBnHkhErzLt", "salt": "b7070f2ca7495e49c85ab41b5a368150e2c217be6d08cc4102a1b682cddb6f01", "referral": ""},"identity":{"primaryaddresses":["RDnf7mH7RQki9b7PqdBD2Er6WXv3DTawGr"],"minimumsignatures":1,"name":"ID","parent":"vrsc-btc@"}}' false 0 zs1s2mteau9tcalvk55cnepw3aq7dr6w7f447pqqkxczat3a02208d3ersx60wz9srw3nkd25ppfny ``` If a currency's ID issuance require permission from the currency's identity then it must sign the name commitment and identity registration. Either use the parent identity to fund those transactions, or receive a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage! What limitations should I be aware of when creating a currency from an ID in Verus?

There are two limitations to be aware of:

1. You cannot create a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name. This can cause problems when referring to the currency or identity, and is not supported.
2. In the GUI, you cannot use the same name as an existing supported currency (such as BTC or ETH) for a PBaaS chain. This limitation is specific to the testnet release and will be removed before mainnet availability.

Either use the parent identity to fund those transactions, or receive a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. What are some limitations to be aware of when working with multi-currency on the Verus testnet?

There are two main limitations to be aware of when working with multi-currency on the Verus testnet:

1. You cannot create a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, rather than its calculated ID. This is not recommended and may cause problems in various cases.
2. In the GUI, if a currency is already supported in the Verus Desktop, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.

```

What is the purpose of the `returntx` parameter in the `registeridentity` command?

The `returntx` parameter in the `registeridentity` command is used to specify whether the command should return a raw transaction for the identity owner to sign. If set to `true`, the command will return a raw transaction that the identity owner can sign to complete the registration process.

verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "67635331cbccb7a2cbf408a9e97b3f8986133964e0315a8b9fd237a5fd95ac8f","namereservation": { "version": 1, "name": "ID", "parent": "i84mndBk2Znydpgm9T9pTjVvBnHkhErzLt", "salt": "b7070f2ca7495e49c85ab41b5a368150e2c217be6d08cc4102a1b682cddb6f01", "referral": ""},"identity":{"primaryaddresses":["RDnf7mH7RQki9b7PqdBD2Er6WXv3DTawGr"],"minimumsignatures":1,"name":"ID","parent":"vrsc-btc@"}}' false 0 zs1s2mteau9tcalvk55cnepw3aq7dr6w7f447pqqkxczat3a02208d3ersx60wz9srw3nkd25ppfny ``` If a currency's ID issuance require permission from the currency's identity then it must sign the name commitment and identity registration. Either use the parent identity to fund those transactions, or receive a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage! What are some limitations to be aware of when working with multi-currency IDs in Verus?

There are two limitations to be aware of when working with multi-currency IDs in Verus:

1. You cannot create a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. This is because using an i-address as a currency name can cause problems when referring to the currency or identity.
2. In the GUI, you cannot use the same name for a PBaaS chain as a currency that is already supported in Verus Desktop, such as BTC or ETH. This limitation will be removed before mainnet availability.

How do I register an identity on the Verus network using the command line?

To register an identity on the Verus network, you can use the following command:
```
verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "67635331cbccb7a2cbf408a9e97b3f8986133964e0315a8b9fd237a5fd95ac8f","namereservation": { "version": 1, "name": "ID", "parent": "i84mndBk2Znydpgm9T9pTjVvBnHkhErzLt", "salt": "b7070f2ca7495e49c85ab41b5a368150e2c217be6d08cc4102a1b682cddb6f01", "referral": ""},"identity":{"primaryaddresses":["RDnf7mH7RQki9b7PqdBD2Er6WXv3DTawGr"],"minimumsignatures":1,"name":"ID","parent":"vrsc-btc@"}}' false 0 zs1s2mteau9tcalvk55cnepw3aq7dr6w7f447pqqkxczat3a02208d3ersx60wz9srw3nkd25ppfny
```

What is required for a currency's ID issuance if permission is needed from the currency's identity?

If a currency's ID issuance requires permission from the currency's identity, then the identity must sign the name commitment and identity registration. This can be done either by using the parent identity to fund those transactions or by receiving a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`.

What is required for an identity to issue a currency in Verus?

For an identity to issue a currency in Verus, the currency's ID issuance must be signed by the currency's identity. This can be done by either using the parent identity to fund the transactions or by receiving a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`.

verus -chain=vrsctest registeridentity '{"txid": "67635331cbccb7a2cbf408a9e97b3f8986133964e0315a8b9fd237a5fd95ac8f","namereservation": { "version": 1, "name": "ID", "parent": "i84mndBk2Znydpgm9T9pTjVvBnHkhErzLt", "salt": "b7070f2ca7495e49c85ab41b5a368150e2c217be6d08cc4102a1b682cddb6f01", "referral": ""},"identity":{"primaryaddresses":["RDnf7mH7RQki9b7PqdBD2Er6WXv3DTawGr"],"minimumsignatures":1,"name":"ID","parent":"vrsc-btc@"}}' false 0 zs1s2mteau9tcalvk55cnepw3aq7dr6w7f447pqqkxczat3a02208d3ersx60wz9srw3nkd25ppfny ``` If a currency's ID issuance require permission from the currency's identity then it must sign the name commitment and identity registration. Either use the parent identity to fund those transactions, or receive a raw transaction to give the identity owner to sign by setting `returntx` to `true`### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.# DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk!
